Class Notes: Strings

  1. Technicalities
  2. Operations on strings
  3. Loops over strings
  4. Basic I/O (input/output)
  1. Technicalities
    Representation of strings, special characters and the like.
    • Quotation marks
      Strings are sequences of characters enclosed in quotes.
      # single-quoted or double-quoted strings are the most common print('single-quotes') print("double-quotes") # triple-quotes can be used for multiline strings print('''first line next line''') print("""spaces are respected""")

    • Escaping
      What if you want to use a quote as a character?
      # \ is a escape character. print("A double quote: \"") # printing a quotation mark print("this will be in one line\nand this will be in the next") # line breaking print("A backslash: \\") # escaping the escape print("A tab (between the brackets): [\t]") # can you see it?
    • Strings are immutable!
      s = "hypothesis" # s[8] = "e" --> TypeError: 'str' object does not support item assignment # We need to create a new string plural = s[:8] + "e" + s[9:] print(plural)
  2. Operations on strings
    • + and * on strings
      # notice the necessary space in one of the strings (the computer will never # add spaces for you, since it does not know when a word ends and another begins print("this " + "that") print("repeat " * 5) print(5 * "again ") # and that's it. Other combinations of string with + and * will fail.
    • Strings are just lists!
      paradox = "this sentence is false" # We can use indices to get characters in a string: print(paradox[0]) print(paradox[1]) print(paradox[2]) print(paradox[3]) # We can get the length of a string print(len(paradox)) # We can slice it print(paradox[5:13]) # however we need print(paradox[0:22:5])
    • But in is smarter
      print(['r','i','n','g'] in ['s','t','r','i','n','g']) # is false # but... print("ring" in "strings") # is true! print("" in "is in *every* string.") print(" " in "isnot")
    • Splitting strings
      simpsons = "homer,marge,lisa,bart,maggie" print(simpsons.split(",")) # anything can be the separator print(simpsons.split("a")) quotes = """\ Dijkstra: Simplicity is prerequisite for reliability. Pirsig: Is it hard? Not if you have the right attitudes. It's having the right attitudes that is hard. Heraclitus: There is nothing permanent except change. Pirsig: For every fact there is an infinity of hypotheses. Dijkstra: Computer science is no more about computers than astronomy is about telescopes. """ # Splitting the lines of text lines = quotes.splitlines() print(lines)
    • Editing strings
      s = "i CaNnot UsE ShIft prOpERlY" # Let's make this uniform lowercase = s.lower() print("lowercase:", lowercase) uppercase = s.upper() print("uppercase:", uppercase) s = " Spacious " # No problem, python can remove trailing whitespaces notrailing = s.strip() print("no trailing:", notrailing) s = "This is hard really hard." # We can replace sequences of characters by others optimist = s.replace("hard", "fun") # and we can tell python how many times to replace (counting from left to right) realist = s.replace("hard", "fun but", 1) print("optimist:", optimist) print("realist:", realist) s = "I really like cheese." # Replace can be used to remove words cautious = s.replace("really ", "") print("cautious:", cautious) # Make sure you tell python *exactly* what you want. # It will follow to the letter, literally! contradict = s.replace("really ", "dis") print("contradict:", contradict)
    • Searching in strings
      s = "How much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood?" # Counting occurrences wood = s.count("wood") # Capitalization is respected! how = s.count("how") print("woods:", wood) print("how:", how) # Check the beginning print("Does it start with 'How'?", s.startswith("How")) print("Does it start with 'wood'?", s.startswith("wood")) # Check the end print("Does it end with 'wood'?", s.endswith("wood")) print("Does it end with 'd?'?", s.endswith("d?")) # Find a substring print("Where is 'wood'?", s.find("wood")) print("Where is 'tree'?", s.find("tree"))

    For more functions on strings, see the API
  3. Loops over strings
    • word = "magnanimous" # Looping through the characters with index: for i in range(len(word)): print(i, word[i]) # Looping through the characters without index: for c in word: print(c, end=".") print() # line breaking names = "Daenerys,Snow,Cersei,Tyrion,Sansa,Arya,Jamie" # Looping through the words in a split string for name in names.split(","): print(name)
  4. Basic I/O (input/output)
    • name = input("Hi, my name is Eliza. What is your name? ") # Waits for a user input print("Hello " + name + "! Nice to meet you.")
